question: <image 1> Which of the following conclusions about the early sixteenth century is most directly supported by the map?
options: ['Portugal was primarily interested in exploration of the African and Asian coasts', 'Vasco de Gama was the first European to embark on intercontinental travel by sea', 'European nations began to look outward for economic opportunities', 'European began mass migrations to distant lands in the early sixteenth century']
description: The image depicts a map showing the path of a late fifteenth-century voyage. The route starts from Lisbon, Portugal, and travels southward along the western coast of Africa, passing by Cape Verde Islands and Natal. It then continues eastward across the Indian Ocean, stopping at Malindi before reaching Calicut in India. The map highlights the Atlantic Ocean and the Indian Ocean, with Africa and parts of Europe and Asia visible. The title of the map reads "Path of a late fifteenth century voyage."
